feed.title: Medusa
feed.subtitle: Medusa is a child theme of Mundana Theme built on Jekyll

entry.title: Relentless
entry.content:
You eventually fall out of it.

For a lot of people it‚Äôs just a getting into and out of. Blockbuster entertainment. You get a ticket, stand in line, look for your seat, sit through the action, get out go home go to sleep wake up go to work‚Ä¶ You know the drill.

I, on the other hand, am one of those nerds. Bro, I need to meditate before I go see a movie. I need to resonate with the vibes on the screen, you know? I don‚Äôt even get popcorn! Look, I don‚Äôt want the sound emanating from my own mouth to put me off, distract me from even one irrelevant line Emma fucking Stone would say to another eternal ga-ga loverboy archetype. It‚Äôs a disease: I‚Äôm a little too serious. It doesn‚Äôt make for good living in these times, bro.

I think you can understand how it‚Äôs been the last few months.

When we hit it off I researched her. I had to know everything, about her, about me, about me with her, about us. We became a unit, an army, a nation. Every little thing that threatened to jeopardize our ‚Äúusness‚Äù like fucking five years down the line I‚Äôd take care of it now. I adjusted so many of my bullshit for hers. Now, don‚Äôt get me wrong, I‚Äôm not saying she didn‚Äôt too, but it‚Äôs a stressful process man. And at one point you start being so much of this new you that you start forgetting what you used to be and the minutest of inconveniences makes you beg that same anxious question - was I better off by myself?

But there‚Äôs no ‚ÄúI‚Äù now, bro. The subject cannot exist in a relationship. I fought through, every month, every week, and then every day. And then when she comes to tell you it‚Äôs over, well, you just shatter.

Is this how it ends ?

I went up to her one last time. It‚Äôs a blockbuster cliche, you know how it goes. The hero goes up to the heroine, she says no, he says ‚Äúplease‚Äù, she says no, yada-yada. I asked her if anything‚Äôs still there. Yeah, I know, it sounds desperate, but i really was desperate. Back against the wall.

She was adamant. I respect that. I‚Äôve been trying to get back ever since. To myself, on my feet, how it used to be, you know? It‚Äôs hard fucking work, man, but I‚Äôm giving it a shot.
entry.summary: You eventually fall out of it.

entry.title: Nightdriver - EIDA
entry.content:
From galaxies distant, our little city of Dhaka could look like a cluster of stars. There‚Äôs just so much light.

Zoom in a little closer, it may look something like the back of a translucent butterfly floating over an abyss.

A little closer (like Google map close) and it‚Äôs a bonafide metropolitan! The sheer urbanity of the city night sky can spur intense political discussions about why we don‚Äôt rival New York or Paris already.

But this is where you should stop it with the zooming. From this point onward, shit falls apart. The illuminated gridlines become insufferable gridlocks. The vibrance is exposed, the spirit is debunked. What is left is a city burnt out from overreaching itself.

Zoom in any more and you get a taste of the real nightlife of this city. It‚Äôs you, a newlywed, sat on a public bus, 3 hours after your office closed. You‚Äôre sweating profusely, you have a 5-hour sleep to catch, and what‚Äôs supposed to be the best time of your life is just slipping away from your fingers. You just can‚Äôt take this anymore. Gggaaaaahhhhh.

Someone get news out to the galaxies. We don‚Äôt want the lights to betray some innocent aliens into this speed trap. I mean, we still make do, but it‚Äôll probably be pretty hard for someone to go from lightspeed to 4 km/h just like that.
entry.summary: From galaxies distant, our little city of Dhaka could look like a cluster of stars. There‚Äôs just so much light.

entry.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
entry.content:
You‚Äôll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll‚Äôs GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.
entry.summary: You‚Äôll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

entry.title: Powerful things you can do with the Markdown editor

link.title: Powerful things you can do with the Markdown editor

entry.content:
There are lots of powerful things you can do with the Markdown editor. If you‚Äôve gotten pretty comfortable with writing in Markdown, then you may enjoy some more advanced tips about the types of things you can do with Markdown!

As with the last post about the editor, you‚Äôll want to be actually editing this post as you read it so that you can see all the Markdown code we‚Äôre using.

Special formatting

As well as bold and italics, you can also use some other special formatting in Markdown when the need arises, for example:

  • strike through
  • ==highlight==
  • *escaped characters*

Writing code blocks

There are two types of code elements which can be inserted in Markdown, the first is inline, and the other is block. Inline code is formatted by wrapping any word or words in back-ticks, like this. Larger snippets of code can be displayed across multiple lines using triple back ticks:

.my-link {
    text-decoration: underline;
}

If you want to get really fancy, you can even add syntax highlighting using Rouge.

Reference lists

The quick brown jumped over the lazy.

Another way to insert links in markdown is using reference lists. You might want to use this style of linking to cite reference material in a Wikipedia-style. All of the links are listed at the end of the document, so you can maintain full separation between content and its source or reference.

Full HTML

Perhaps the best part of Markdown is that you‚Äôre never limited to just Markdown. You can write HTML directly in the Markdown editor and it will just work as HTML usually does. No limits! Here‚Äôs a standard YouTube embed code as an example:
entry.summary: There are lots of powerful things you can do with the Markdown editor. If you‚Äôve gotten pretty comfortable with writing in Markdown, then you may enjoy some more advanced tips about the types of things you can do with Markdown!

entry.title: The first mass-produced book to deviate from a rectilinear format

link.title: The first mass-produced book to deviate from a rectilinear format

entry.content:
The first mass-produced book to deviate from a rectilinear format, at least in the United States, is thought to be this 1863 edition of Red Riding Hood, cut into the shape of the protagonist herself with the troublesome wolf curled at her feet. Produced by the Boston-based publisher Louis Prang, this is the first in their ‚ÄúDoll Series‚Äù, a set of five ‚Äúdie-cut‚Äù books, known also as shape books ‚Äî the other titles being Robinson Crusoe, Goody Two-Shoes (also written by Red Riding Hood author Lydia Very), Cinderella, and King Winter.

An 1868 Prang catalogue would later claim that such ‚Äúbooks in the shape of a regular paper Doll‚Ä¶ originated with us‚Äù.

It would seem the claim could also extend to die cut books in general, as we can‚Äôt find anything sooner, but do let us know in the comments if you have further light to shed on this! Such books are, of course, still popular in children‚Äôs publishing today, though the die cutting is not now limited to mere outlines, as evidenced in a beautiful 2014 version of the same Little Red Riding Hood story.

The die cut has also been employed in the non-juvenile sphere as well, a recent example being Jonathan Safran Foer‚Äôs ambitious Tree of Codes.

As for this particular rendition of Charles Perrault‚Äôs classic tale, the text and design is by Lydia Very (1823-1901), sister of Transcendentalist poet Jones Very. The gruesome ending of the original - which sees Little Red Riding Hood being gobbled up as well as her grandmother - is avoided here, the gore giving way to the less bloody aims of the morality tale, and the lesson that one should not disobey one‚Äôs mother.

To deviate from a rectilinear format, at least in the United States, is thought to be this 1863 edition of Red Riding Hood, cut into the shape of the protagonist herself with the troublesome wolf curled at her feet. Produced by the Boston-based publisher Louis Prang, this is the first in their ‚ÄúDoll Series‚Äù, a set of five ‚Äúdie-cut‚Äù books, known also as shape books ‚Äî the other titles being Robinson Crusoe, Goody Two-Shoes (also written by Red Riding Hood author Lydia Very), Cinderella, and King Winter.

An 1868 Prang catalogue would later claim that such ‚Äúbooks in the shape of a regular paper Doll‚Ä¶ originated with us‚Äù.

The claim could also extend to die cut books in general, as we can‚Äôt find anything sooner, but do let us know in the comments if you have further light to shed on this! Such books are, of course, still popular in children‚Äôs publishing today, though the die cutting is not now limited to mere outlines, as evidenced in a beautiful 2014 version of the same Little Red Riding Hood story.

The die cut has also been employed in the non-juvenile sphere as well, a recent example being Jonathan Safran Foer‚Äôs ambitious Tree of Codes.

As for this particular rendition of Charles Perrault‚Äôs classic tale, the text and design is by Lydia Very (1823-1901), sister of Transcendentalist poet Jones Very. The gruesome ending of the original - which sees Little Red Riding Hood being gobbled up as well as her grandmother - is avoided here, the gore giving way to the less bloody aims of the morality tale, and the lesson that one should not disobey one‚Äôs mother.
entry.summary: The first mass-produced book to deviate from a rectilinear format, at least in the United States, is thought to be this 1863 edition of Red Riding Hood, cut into the shape of the protagonist herself with the troublesome wolf curled at her feet. Produced by the Boston-based publisher Louis Prang, this is the first in their ‚ÄúDoll Series‚Äù, a set of five ‚Äúdie-cut‚Äù books, known also as shape books ‚Äî the other titles being Robinson Crusoe, Goody Two-Shoes (also written by Red Riding Hood author Lydia Very), Cinderella, and King Winter.
